senses.de: To leave a place, especially going to another place
senses.ex: The train will depart from platform 1

Tips.title: Physical Movement
Tips.description: Use 'depart' when someone moves from one specific place to another.
Tips.example: She will depart from Chicago at dawn.

Tips.title: Planned Time
Tips.description: 'Depart at' usually indicates a scheduled time for leaving, often in transport.
Tips.example: The flight is scheduled to depart at 6 PM.

Tips.title: Preposition Choice
Tips.description: After 'depart', use 'from' for starting points and 'for' for destinations.
Tips.example: The bus will depart from Leeds for Manchester.

senses.de: To go away from an expected plan or standard
senses.ex: They decided to depart from the original plan

Tips.title: Unexpected Change
Tips.description: Use 'depart' to describe a change from a plan, which can be unexpected or unusual.
Tips.example: We'll depart from the usual format in today's meeting.

Tips.title: Alternative Action
Tips.description: It can imply choosing a different method or approach intentionally.
Tips.example: This recipe departs from the traditional one.

senses.de: To die, to leave this world
senses.ex: When our beloved grandmother departed, it was a great loss for our family

Tips.title: Euphemism for Death
Tips.description: It is a more formal and less direct way to talk about someone dying.
Tips.example: The old sailor had departed at a ripe age.

Tips.title: Historical Usage
Tips.description: The concept of 'depart this world' can be found in classical literature.
Tips.example: In the novel, the hero departs this life nobly.

senses.ex: They departed on their adventure with excitement

Tips.title: Journey's Commencement
Tips.description: Specifically used when someone begins a planned trip or expedition.
Tips.example: They departed on their honeymoon with joy.

Tips.title: Adventure Inference
Tips.description: Often implies leaving for an adventure or a significant journey.
Tips.example: The explorers departed for the unknown.

Go away.wordDefinition:
Both depart and go away mean to leave a certain place, but depart is a more formal and polite way to say it. Depart is commonly used in formal settings such as airports, train stations or formal emails, whereas go away is more casual and used in everyday language.

Go away can also imply a sense of annoyance or irritation while depart is neutral. Eg: "I'm departing from the airport" vs "Please go away, you're bothering me".

Leave.wordDefinition:
Both depart and leave mean to go away or to exit but depart is typically used in more formal or official contexts. For example, a plane departs from the airport or a soldier departs for duty.

Leave is more commonly used in everyday conversation and refers to the act of going away from a place or a person. For instance, someone might say "I'm leaving work early today" or "I'm leaving the party now".

Depart is more formal while leave is more casual.

Move out.wordDefinition:
Move out typically refers to physically leaving a residence or dwelling, such as moving out of a house or apartment.

Both terms can be applicable in a variety of situations, but depart is often used in professional or formal contexts, while move out is more commonly used in informal or personal settings.

For example, a businessman might depart from a conference room, while a college student might move out of a dorm room.

Retire.wordDefinition:
Depart refers to leaving or going away from a particular place or situation, while retire refers to leaving a job or career permanently or for an extended period of time.

If someone is retiring from work, it means that they are leaving their career permanently and will no longer work in that field.

Depart means leaving a place or situation, while retire means leaving a career or job permanently.

Set out.wordDefinition:
The words depart and set out are both used to describe leaving a place, but there is a subtle difference between them.

Set out, on the other hand, is a more casual verb that is often used to describe starting a journey with some enthusiasm or purpose.

It suggests a sense of adventure or excitement. For example, you might say "We set out early in the morning to hike to the top of the mountain.".

Depart is more formal and serious, while set out is more casual and adventurous.

Start out.wordDefinition:
The words depart and start out mean the same thing: to leave a place and begin a journey. Depart is a more formal word and is commonly used in situations like airports, train stations, and official documents.

Start out is a more casual word and is commonly used in everyday conversations. For example, you could say "I departed from the airport" or "I started out from my house.".

Take off.wordDefinition:
Both depart and take off are words used to express the starting of a journey or leaving one place to go to another.

Take off specifically refers to leaving by air.

It describes the moment when a plane lifts off the ground and begins to fly. For example, the plane will take off at 3 pm.

So, in short, depart is a more general term for leaving any place, while take off specifically refers to leaving by air.

Vacate.wordDefinition:
Vacate means to leave a place or position that you are occupying, such as a house, room or job. It often implies that the place or position will be left empty or available for someone else to take.

For example, "We need to vacate the apartment by the end of the month because the lease is up."

Depart is used when leaving a location, while vacate describes leaving a position or place vacant.

Withdraw.wordDefinition:
Withdraw means to remove something or someone from a particular situation or location. It means to take away or pull back.

Depart is used to indicate someone leaving a specific place or position, while withdraw is used to indicate the removal of something or someone from a certain situation or location.

quotes.Text: My dear mamma is quite right when she says that we must lay down principles and not depart from them. The king will not have the same weaknesses as his grandfather. I hope that he will have no favorites; but I am afraid that he is too mild and too easy. You may depend upon it that I will not draw the king into any great expenses.
quotes.Title: French Royalty
quotes.Name: Marie Antoinette

quotes.Text: Nature is forever arriving and forever departing, forever approaching, forever vanishing; but in her vanishings there seems to be ever the waving of a hand, in all her partings a promise of meetings farther along the road.
quotes.Title: English Poet
quotes.Name: Richard Le Gallienne

quotes.Text: As women in industrial societies join the paid workforce, they gain the economic means to depart unhappy marriages more easily.
quotes.Title: American Scientist
quotes.Name: Helen Fisher

quotes.Text: Nothing that was worthy in the past departs; no truth or goodness realized by man ever dies, or can die.
quotes.Title: Scottish Philosopher
quotes.Name: Thomas Carlyle

quotes.Text: The truth is of course is that there is no journey. We are arriving and departing all at the same time.
quotes.Title: English Musician
quotes.Name: David Bowie

quotes.Text: Tomorrow morning before we depart, I intend to land and see what can be found in the neighborhood.
quotes.Title: Italian Explorer
quotes.Name: Christopher Columbus

quotes.Text: Life itself is but the shadow of death, and souls departed but the shadows of the living.
quotes.Title: British Scientist
quotes.Name: Thomas Browne

quotes.Text: The great business of life is to be, to do, to do without and to depart.
quotes.Title: British Statesman
quotes.Name: John Morley

quotes.Text: So that he seemed to depart not from life, but from one home to another.
quotes.Title: Roman Author
quotes.Name: Cornelius Nepos

quotes.Text: We would like to see you departing peacefully.
quotes.Title: South African Leader
quotes.Name: Desmond Tutu
